channel.title: Mini Farm
channel.description:
Epic. My new processor didn't work in my computer, so I basically built a whole new one instead of swapping out a motherboard and having a useless CPU lying around.
So. I got a new motherboard, four more gigs of RAM, and a new HDD.
So now, I've got two computers hooked up. Both to the same 22" widescreen monitor.
The main one: QX6850 @ 3.0Ghz x 4 4GB RAM nVidia 9800GTX 500GB HDD
The other: Q6600 @ 2.6 x 4 4GB RAM 500GB HDD
Both running Vista 64bit Ultimate.
Getting them both set up now for some distributed rendering so I'll have a miniature render farm.

item.title: Mini Farm
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Eh. 4 gigs doesn’t all get recognized with 32bit, and I only had one or two times I was working on something and it ran out of memory. But after optimizing it didn’t matter.

Now I doubt I’ll have any problems. If I do, I can always get more.

Read full topic

item.description:

There are a ton of GPU Ray-tracing examples written with the CUDA SDK, take a look at demo/example projects on nvidia’s website.[/quote]

Yes, but are they anywhere near as powerful or as advanced as any major market renderer right now?

item.title: Mini Farm
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman

SomethingToHide:

It’s all done building on the basics of raytracing. GPU’s don’t do it that way.

Yet.

Read full topic

item.title: Mini Farm
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

No. It’s not what games do. There’s a difference.

GPU’s work with games by rasterization.

CPU’s work with calculating everything for the final image by raytracing.

It’s all done building on the basics of raytracing. GPU’s don’t do it that way.

Raytracing is more realistic. It’s how reality works and that’s why it’s superior in this case.

GPU’s rasterizing uses a shitload of layers of things like shadows, lighting, atmosphere, everything to make it look real. It fakes reality.
Not what we’re trying to achieve in this case.

There’s also a lot of reasons why it’s taking so long for GPU’s to even be thought of for stuff like this. GPU’s are proprietary. CPU’s aren’t.

GPU manufacturers don’t really release all the stuff going on in the inside to make it programmable.

Read full topic

item.title: Mini Farm
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Uh, what you just described is exactly what games do. Have you not heard of shadows, shaders and lighting?

However, I agree with you that nothing renders using a GPU atm - no reason it couldn’t happen, though.

Read full topic

item.title: Mini Farm
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Everything that was just said was wrong basically.

GPU’s do not help in the rendering of this. Google some info about the aspects of rendering.

GPU’s ARE used in the rendering of games. GPU’s AREN’T used for rendering from a 3D app.

It’s WAY more complicated than I think a GPU can handle. Millions of rays are sent from sources and have to bounce around realistically according to complex algorithms and sometimes double when bounced. Each ray is influenced by the angle of a bounce, all the material properties, how many times it’s bounced, etc.

It’s actually a lot slower for a GPU to handle. Game engines are heavily optimized and baked and made for GPU’s to handle, while the CPU is doing a bunch of other shit. Render engines are CPU and RAM users. Not GPU’s.

None of this stuff is real time. I see almost no use for a GPU in rendering besides an aid. I highly doubt it will be GPU centered later on, unless we start seeing some monster multicore fast as shit card.

Read full topic

item.title: Mini Farm
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Unhandled:

GPUs are designed for rendering movies and graphics much more efficiently than CPUs, regardless of the target output media.

Maybe so, but I don’t know of a single modelling package that uses the GPU to render (by default, there’s probably plugins)

Read full topic

item.title: Mini Farm
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

la­wl:

i thought it was mostly the graphix card that renders shit, so shouldnt you have a good one in both

Not at all. It plays almost NO role at all.

If you have a shitty ass one maybe the end product will look different locally. Not to everyone else.

And if you’re working with intense scenes with millions of polygons, it’ll be MUCH slower.

But it plays no role in the rendering process.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: December 31, 2008, 01:17:55 am[/size][hr]

PS: Progress:

So far on my main computer I have all my programs installed, and I just finished testing of VRay and RenderMan clients. Both working.

Now, I need to reformat the other and install Vista64 on it, then install all these programs on that and test the servers on that one.

Once this is straightened out, unless I choose not to, everything I render will be split amongst the computers.

Fucking sweet.

Read full topic
